awd_titl_txt: Documenting Traditional Ecological Knowledge in the Sierra Nororiental de Puebla, Mexico, in Synchronic and Diachronic Perspectives
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to understand the diversity and potential benefits of plant life around the world and to assess the impact of the loss of biodiversity, it is necessary to create an accurate floristic inventory of bio-diverse regions  and to record the evolving  interactions of humans with that rich environment.  To this end, botanist John Kress of the Smithsonian will use innovative DNA barcoding methodology to facilitate rapid identification to species of the flora specimens collected in five Nahuat and two Totonac villages in the 28 municipalities of the Sierra Nororiental de Puebla, Mexico -- an incredibly bio-diverse region of the world.  Working in tandem with Kress, linguist Jonathan Amith of Gettysburg College will use state-of-the-art language documentation techniques to create an extensive digital database of recordings of native experts discussing traditional nomenclature and classification of local flora.  The linguistic and botanical databases will support the preservation of indigenous knowledge about the biodiversity of this region. 

Amith and Kress hypothesize that accessing botanical information from endangered languages will help track changes in the ecology of the ancestral homelands of endangered language communities.  In addition, Amith and Kress theorize that comparative botanical information across geographically proximate villages will reveal historical patterns of migration, cultural contact, and language change.  Using data from the endangered language discussions about plant life in the region and DNA barcode reference library, Amith will study shifts of biotaxa nomenclature.  He will use clues from lexical borrowing and calques to map the spread of knowledge about particular botanical specimens and link that spread to community migrations.  

Data will be stored in various herbariums in Mexico and at the Smithsonian Museum.  Linguistic data will be accessible at the Archive of Indigenous Languages of Latin America.  This project supported by NSF's Office of International and Integrative Activities because it enhances research excellence through international collaboration with faculty at Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM) and will benefit from use of local resources such as the National Herbarium of Mexico and the Comisión Nacional Para El Connocimineto Y Uso De La Biodiversidad.

por.por_cntn:
?Documenting Traditional Ecological Knowledge in the Sierra Nororiental de Puebla, Mexico, in Synchronic and Diachronic Perspectives? is a long-term effort to document the nomenclature, classification, and economic and symbolic use of plants in Nahuatl and Totonac villages in the northern sierras of the state of Puebla, Mexico. The attention to data from multiple communities reflects the importance of comparative data for understanding the cultural history of linguistic groups.

First, lexical similarities among historically related groups (e.g., French ?ami[e]? and Spanish ?amigo[a]?) can be used to reconstruct ancient (proto-)forms. Reconstructed proto-forms for flora and fauna shed light on the ecology of ancestral homelands as these forms demonstrate the presence of particular plants and animals in the ancestral communities before they diverged. Comparative ethnobiological studies among dispersed communities descended from a single, ancient language can also reveal processes of lexicosemantic change: the factors that affect relative retention, loss, and semantic shift in the nomenclature of biotaxa.

Second, the presence of loans, calques, and shared beliefs and uses of  plants and animals among communities that not descended from a common ancestor reflects historical patterns of migration and contact. Migrating populations, as opposed to those that are geographically stable, probably manifest higher rates of change in biosemantic terms than in other areas of the lexicon. Thus as human populations move into ecosystems with biotaxa distinct from that of their place of origin, new species encountered may be named by (1) semantic shift of extant terms to new denotata, (2) borrowing from languages encountered in the new habitat, or (3) neologisms, most likely descriptive, semantically transparent terminology.

While the theoretical implications for comparative study of the nomenclature, classification, and use of plants and animals is clear, the design of a single project able to gather data from many distinct and dispersed communities is difficult. The present project has met this challenge in several ways:

--- First, it has assembled and trained native speakers (particularly biologists and linguists) interested in documenting the flora, fauna, and traditional ecological knowledge of their communities of origin through plant collection, high-quality in situ photography, digital audio recording, and transcription and translation of their native tongue (the plants documented in the Zongozotla Totonac illustrated field guide were all collected, photographed, and partially identified by a native speaker biologist from that community).

--- Second, it has created a vast network (>150) of expert taxonomists who are not only able to fairly rapidly identify specimens to species (from photos and physical vouchers) but who are interested in collaborating on a project, such as this, that tries to address the research agendas and career ambitions of all team members.

--- Third, this project has assembled a vast amount of varied material useful for plant identification and the documentation of traditional ecological knowledge: (a) > 10,000 physical plant specimens; (b) > 25,000 high quality in situ photographs (expert taxonomists have been able to identify 75% of specimens to species from these photographs, with few errors corrected upon review of physical specimens); (c) hundreds of recordings of three types: (i) high quality two-channel audio of conversations among native speakers [almost all have been transcribed and most translated]; (ii) field recordings of native experts made at the site and time of plant collection [all have been summarized]; (iii) word tokens of plant names in many communities in which fieldwork has taken place.

--- Fourth, this project has initiated a potentially transformative approach to ethnobiological documentation: the use of DNA sequencing and the creation of a DNA ?barcode? reference library that could be used in the future to facilitate identification of plants through DNA sequencing instead of sending dried plant specimens to expert taxonomists. A proof of concept case of this methodology is being developed with ferns, a group for which one gene, rbcL, is extremely effective as a unique identifying marker for distinct species. The DNA barcode reference library is based on 1063 tissue samples representing ~ 325 fern species, one-third of the total in Mexico and virtually all those present in the state of Puebla.

Over the years, this project has attracted wide support from additional funding agencies in the United States, Mexico and England. This enabled the targeting of additional Nahuatl and Totonac villages and the addition of four Mixtec communities from Guerrero.

Finally, a particularly important development has been the contribution of other funding agencies to creating two web portals designed to disseminate project results to a wide range of potential stakeholders: (a) DEMCA: Documenting the Ethnobiology of Mexico and Central America and (b) Mesolex: Lexicosemantic Resources for Mesoamerican Languages.  Screenshots of these portals are included in the images, where the URLs are presented. The portals will disseminate the results of this project in ways that are particulary useful to researchers, to the general public, and to native speakers and communities.
